content.description:
Fantastic position from the belay and throughout much of the climb.  Stellar cracks and great gear other than one short run out near the top.  A steep and exciting but well protected crux twenty feet above the belay.

You must climb the Dance Platform to access this climb.  From the top of Dance Platform step up and left. Follow the crack up and then right through a groove. When it branches off, stay on the left crack that leads to a short slab. Rap either the tree or the two bolt rap station on the top.
Standard rack to 3" is fine here.  Save you 2" piece for the upper cracks.

This is a nice direct line to the top of the cliff.  Makes a great link up with Fake Right-Go Left.  Very straight forward climbing on good quality stone.

Located directly above Fake Right Go Left.  From the pitch one Magic X belay station head straight up on cracks and ledges to the top of the cliff.
Standard rack to 3".  Two bolt anchor/rappel station at the top.

Head up the slab directly below the right side of the roof. Move right at an overhang slightly below the roof. Minimal to no pro here but 5.0 climbing. Step right onto the lip of the overhang. Make a diagonal foot traverse on good quality rock moving toward Magic X. Follow the bolts up through overhangs and slabs. The route merges with Magic X briefly then moves toward the left side of the X Wall. The last bolt you will clip is the bolt on 50 Mission Cap. From there move up and left aiming for a short hand crack with jug above. Continue up on cracks and jugs to a left leaning wide crack. Work your feet up this crack to the top of the cliff and the left hand side of the Magic X/Up Yours/50 Mission belay ledge.

Gear: single rack to 3 with lots of draws. Small cams/nuts will protect any run outs between the bolts. A blue alien to protect the crux moves after the bolts.


Start above the large Spruce tree near the bottom of the X Wall, 10 meters below the 50 Mission Cap roof.
Single rack to 3" piece. Small cams protect two cruxes. About a dozen draws. Fixed anchor.

Ascend a crack system to a large flat ledge. Enjoyable climbing on beautiful granite with excellent gear throughout. There are two finishes to this climb. One goes left through a v groove and the other goes just right underneath the large ledge. Both are good but the right variation is slightly more challenging.  Start on the crack riddled slab that reaches all the way down to the trail. Move up over this easy bit to the base of an overhanging diagonal crack. This is about 15 feet left of the corner. Continue through the right diagonal crack to get on top of the block and in the v shaped groove. Once on top of the block continue to the Dance Platform ledge going either straight up or around to the left.
*The original variation goes to the right, starting in the corner and then moving back left to the shallow groove. It is awkward and difficult to protect.  Standard rack to 3".

climbs.name: Emerald City
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Denise Hamel, Mike Parker

content.description:
Crux is down low on steeper terrain.  A little spice to gain the upper ramp.

Start is just right of Up Yours and follows the arête onto a crack filled ramp to a 2 bolt rap station. Gear and moves are a bit tricky for the first 25 feet then it becomes very straight forward.
Standard rack to 3".  Bolted anchor.

climbs.name: Fake Right - Go Left
climbs.fa: Shawn Bethune, Denise Hamel and Greg Hughes

content.description:
Climb straight up behind the tree on lower angle rock in the shallow right facing corner slightly to the right of Magic X. Climb steep cracks and flakes aiming for an obvious wide crack that slants to the right. Gain the narrow buttress above and follow a crack along the left edge. Exciting climbing up the crack and a few face moves leads to the Magic X anchor. Beautiful climbing, excellent gear and thrilling exposure.

Start on a crack riddled slab below a large spruce tree that has the sign "X Wall" on it. Climb up to the tree. Rap the route and remember to tie knots in your rope.  A 60 meter rope will get you to the ground with some easy downclimbing.
A #4 or #5 will allow for higher gear placements in the wide crack but is not necessary. A 70 meter rope is needed to get you back to your packs.

There is a lot of variety packed into this long pitch.  An easy start, a roof to surmount, a long corner providing great stemming, a short but tricky bolt protected traverse and to finish off this test of endurance - a burly crack section. Watch out for rope drag.

At the X Wall look for a big roof about 50 feet off the deck.  The route starts just above a large spruce tree in the corner system below the roof.
Standard rack to 3".  Maybe double up from .5 to #1 camalots.  One bolt protects a techy traverse.  Bolted rappel stations get you to the ground.

Climb cracks staying just left of The Crack Machine.  Fairly sustained throughout.  Wild, exposed climbing on some very cool features.

Same start as Dance Platform but move right after 20 feet up into a series of overhanging flakes that follow the left side of the arête until it blends into the wall above. Descend in two rappels with a single rope.
Standard rack to 3".  A 4" piece could prove useful.  Two bolt rap station at the top.

Pitch 1 starts on a corner crack system below the "X Wall" sign. Climb up through easy ground and then move slightly left through a slab feature to a corner crack system. Climb the crack to a perfect belay ledge and bolted anchor. This pitch is as good or better than the second. 130 feet

Pitch 2 eats gear and follows the left leaning hand/fist crack that straightens and narrows to fingers near the top. 90 feet

Nice clean granite with fantastic cracks make for some splendid climbing from top to bottom. Probably the best two pitch route at the cliff.


Single rack to 3" maybe double up on 1 to 3 for pitch 2.  Anchor is shared with Up Yours and Fifty Mission Cap.  Use the Emerald City anchor on your second rappel to get back to your packs.

This route starts from the Dance Platform (climb pitch 1 of Dance Platform).
From the right end of the platform, pull a V5-6 boulder problem up the overhanging panel of rock past 2 bolts, staying on the face. After the second bolt, pull around the arête and merge with Harvest.

This is a 2nd pitch which starts from the dance platform. The 2 bolts are visible from the ground, up a black streak on overhanging rock.
2 bolts for the crux. standard rack afterwards

climbs.name: Salad Fingers
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Denise Hamel, Mike Parker

content.description:
Two cruxes, one is the in the dihedral of Fifty Mission and the second is the diagonal crack.  Sustained climbing through the first pitch on bullet hard granite. Beautiful movement. This route combined with Emerald City or the first pitch of Up Yours makes for a long 3 pitch link up of excellent quality.


To access this route you need to get to the bolted anchor of Emerald City. From there continue up the ramp until it joins the corner crack that is part of 50 Mission Cap. Head up through the corner crack system then move right to clip a bolt after the corner crack disappears. From the bolt follow a long, right diagonal finger crack that leads to a ledge. Gain the ledge and belay at a bolted anchor. From here you can continue up to the top of the cliff or rappel. 

Standard rack to 3".  Small gear protects the hardest climbing.    Some may want to double up on nuts or small gear.  A bolt protects a blank section through the traverse toward the diagonal crack.

The rock quality on this route is what really stands out. Steep climbing right off the belay. The crux comes pulling the overhang. Pleasant climbing after the crux. Cross over Anatomy Lesson or join it before reaching a tree anchor at the top of the cliff. 

You must climb the Dance Platform in order to access this route. From the DP ledge step left from the bolted anchor and move up through a corner to the overhang. 
Small gear protects the crux moves. Single rack to 3. Tree anchor.
Enter a description of this area.
